Okay so I felt bad about feeding Maisie Williams what I would charitably call a very very dry biscuit

so I tried a few other recipes ranging
from whole wheat breads to crackers and

nothing really came out quite right they
either came out too dense or too dry

because they need to hold their shape
when they're baking. Finally I found one

that looks semi accurate and still
tastes good it's a brown butter pecan

scone. We're starting by making a half
cup of brown butter we're gonna put that in the

freezer while we wait for that to freeze
solid we're gonna measure out 85 grams

of whole wheat flour 85 grams of
all-purpose flour combine those in a

medium bowl and resolve to follow
through on your bold choice as you add

1/2 teaspoon of salt 1 teaspoon of
baking powder and 1/4 teaspoon of baking

soda we're also gonna add just shy of
1/4 cup of white sugar whisk to combine

and let's get the butter going as you
can see it as frozen very very solid

we're gonna scoop it out into the dry
ingredients and then I'm gonna try out

this pastry cutter to cut up set butter..
what... did I stutter motherf- sorry

this is a family show anyway we're
cutting the butter down into pea-sized

pieces then we're gonna add some sage;
fresh sage freshly chopped and some

pecans that we have toasted and let cool
completely. We're just giving this a

little tossy toss to make sure that
everybody's gotten to know each other

before adding 1/2 of 1 cup of buttermilk
folding gently to combine making sure

that we don't break down all those nice
hunks of butter we're turning this out

onto a lightly floured countertop
working in just a little bit we don't to

build up gluten and patting it into a
disc large enough that we might cut a

direwolf from it we're brushing this guy
down with a beaten egg and baking it 425

degrees Fahrenheit for about 20 minutes
or until a lovely shade of golden brown

we're cooling this on a rack because
it's really really really hot out but we

still want to serve it warm so we can
melt some honey butter over top to make

honey butter simply combine a ratio of 2
parts butter to one part honey mix well

to combine and spread it on stuff
because it tastes really really really

good and so does the scone it's light
and tender and flaky and the flavors all

play really nice together it's a member
of the clean tail and hind quarters club

(British accent) All right bakers 20 minutes... Bakers you
now have vingt minutes!
